fields.headline: Striking a balance
fields.bodyText: The challenge To close the gap between the level of pension required and that expected if the present system does not change The difficulties Pickering tries to strike a balance between three areas: · Work place giving employers greater control over the design of the pension scheme while protecting members' (employees) rights · Marketplace giving the product providers an incentive to produce suitable pension schemes but at the same time protecting consumers from bad practice · The people balancing the interests of existing members with those who are not Suggested solutions · A new pensions act that would repeal or consolidate all the existing private pensions legislation. It would change the emphasis from strict rules to principles that the pension schemes would adopt · A pension is a pension is a pension. Regardless of whether the scheme is run by an employer or an individual company, the regulations should be same; members should have the same level of protection · Build up as large a pension pot as possible, so: - employers should be allowed to force employees to join their schemes - members of pension schemes should be given their rights when they join, and not be forced to wait for two years - easier transfer of pensions between employers - end the requirement that pensions should increase in line with inflation - end the requirement that spouses continue to receive benefits after the death of the pensioner · A new kind of regulator (NKR) offering more far-reaching judgment and advice and is more proactive
